often associated with substances or weapons.', 'Genocide - The deliberate killing of a large group of people, especially those of a particular ethnic group or nation.', "Euthanasia (non-medical context) - The act of intentionally ending a person's life to relieve suffering; ["Blindspots - Areas in a horse's field of view where it cannot see.", "Lateral ophthalmic nerve (Horner's syndrome) - Can affect pupil size and, indirectly, peripheral vision in horses.", "Horse blinders (Blinders or Eyeshields) - Attachments to a horse's bridle that limit visual range to the side without restrainting sight entirely.", 'Retina - Part of the eye responsible for processing light and contributing to peripheral vision.', 'Corneal opacity - Scarring or cloudiness on the cornea can obstruct a horse’s vision.', 'Uveitis (Equine Recurrent Uveitis) - An inflammation that may cause decreased visual acuity, though not typically limiting peripheral vision directly.', "Cataracts - Clouding of the eye's lens can affect overall vision clarity and indirectly impact peripheral vision.", 'Glaucoma - Increased intraocular pressure that can lead to optic nerve damage, potentially affecting peripheral vision over time.', 'Anophthalmia (absence of one or both eyes) – Complete lack of a visual field in the affected eye/s if it were present.', 'Strabismus - Misalignment of the eyes, which can lead to double vision but not directly limit peripheral sighting unless associated with other conditions affecting vision.', "Amblyopia (Lazy Eye) - A condition where a horse's visual development in one eye is compromised; if only one eye were affected, it would reduce overall field of view but does not typically limit the unimpaired eye's peripheral vision directly.", 'Macular degeneration (Central Vision Loss) - Primarily affects central visual acuity in horses and doesn’t directly limit peripheral vision.', 'Ocular neoplasia - Growth within the eye that can obscure vision if located centrally but may not significantly impact peripheral vision.', 'Anisocoria (unequal pupil sizes) - Can result from various conditions, affecting overall visual acuity but doesn’t inherently limit peripheral sight unless associated with other eye abnormalities.', 'Optic neuritis - Inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause vision loss; if unilateral, it would primarily impact central vision in one eye.', 'Keratitis (Inflamed Cornea) - Causes pain and blurred vision but does not directly limit peripheral sighting unless severe scarring occurs.', "Photophobia (Sensitivity to Light) – While it affects the comfort of light exposure, it doesn't inherently limit visual field breadth.", 'Mydriasis (Dilated pupils) - Can be a result of various conditions but does not directly impair peripheral vision unless associated with other issues.', "Exophthalmia (Protrusion of the eyeball) – Can potentially affect field of view if severe, though it's more an effect than a cause that limits peripheral vision.", 'Ocular melanosis - Discoloration or pigmentation changes in the eye; may alter visual appearance but doesn’t inherently limit peripheral sighting.']

['Cyclops - A one-eyed, mythological giant from Greek and Roman folklore.', 'Goliath - In Biblical stories, Goliath was a fearsome Philistine warrior who fought against David.', 'Behemoth - In the Book of Job in the Hebrew Bible, behemoth is described as a wicked giant creature.', 'Titans - Ancient Greek mythology tells of powerful beings known as the Titans, some of whom were giants.', 'Jormungandr - A gigantic sea serpent from Norse mythology who coils around Midgard (the world).', 'Typhon - In Greek mythology, a monstrous giant and one-eyed king of all monsters.', 'Sleipnir - Although not a wicked giant, this eight-legged horse in Norse mythology was the mount of Odin, often associated with giants due to its size.', 'Gigantes - In Greek mythology, the Giants were powerful beings who fought against Zeus and other Olympian gods.', 'Hydra - A multi-headed serpent from Greek mythology, though not a giant per se, it was considered wicked due to its immortality and regenerative abilities.', "Chimera - In Greek mythology, this creature was a fire-breathing monster that combined the features of different animals, including a lion's head, goat's body, and serpent tail.", 'Minotaur - A creature from Greek mythology with the body of a man and the head of a bull; some legends suggest it was raised by King Minos as an offering to Poseidon, making him wickedly powerful.', 'Cybeles - Mythical creatures in Greek mythology who were half-nymph, half-snake beings with the bodies of serpents and the heads of women.', 'Keres (plural: Keres) - In Greek mythology, they are the spirits of violent or cruel death; not a giant but related to wickedness.', "Harpy - Mythological creatures from ancient Greek and Roman mythology with bird-like wings, often depicted as agents of vengeance who steal people's souls in their sleep.", 'Titaness (plural: Titans) - In Greek mythology, these were the divine beings that predated the Olympian gods; they could have been considered wicked giants due to some stories involving them as adversaries of Zeus and his followers.', 'Echidna - A monstrous creature from Greek mythology who was half-woman, half-snake, known for giving birth to many other monstrous creatures including the Chimera.', 'Nemean Lion - In Greek mythology, a wicked and unkillable lion whose skin became impervious when exposed to mortal weapons; although not a giant, it was one of the Twelve Labors of Hercules.', "Hydra - While typically depicted with multiple heads rather than as an overall 'giant,' this mythical monster is often associated with wickedness and strength due to its ability to regenerate from severed parts.", 'Minerva (Minerva in Roman mythology) - Although not a giant, the goddess of wisdom, warfare, and crafts was sometimes portrayed as having a large stature, symbolizing her power and strength.', 'Titansomnia - A fictional term combining "Titan," giants from Greek mythology, with "insomnia." It would refer to the condition where one imagines themselves as these powerful creatures in their dreams or thoughts.']

CLUE: Beaver-like rodent with dark glossy brown fur
OUTPUT: ['Castoridae', 'Alces (moose) - Not typically beaver-like, but included for comparison due to its size and forest habitat.', "Aplodontia (Aplodont hog) – An ancient rodent with a bear-like appearance not exactly matching the description; however, it's often discussed alongside beavers in mammalian contexts.", 'Castor canadensis (North American Beaver) - Direct match to both the clue and characteristics.', 'Castor fiber (European Beaver) – The European counterpart matching the description closely.', 'Ondatra zibethicus (Muskrat) – While not beaver-like, it shares some habitat preferences with beavers.', 'Punuk - A term used by Inuit to refer specifically to the North American Beaver due to its significance in their culture.', 'Castoroides (Giant Beavers) – An extinct genus of giant beavers that had similar features but lived during prehistoric times.', 'Myoxes - A term used for members of the family Myxidae, which includes some species with fur-like textures and colorings that can resemble those of a beaver', 'Castorine – An adjective referring specifically to something pertaining to or characteristic of the beaver.', "Sagittal - While this refers to anatomical location rather than a species, it's included for its relation to the distinctive shape of a beaver’inaside (a rodent family) – Not directly beaver-like but included due to close relation within mammalian taxonomy.", 'Castorid - An adjective describing something related to or characteristic of the castorids, an extinct order that includes early beaver ancestors.', "Aplodontia (Aplodont hog) – Although not exactly matching the description and typically considered a prehistoric species, it's included for its historical significance in discussions about rodent evolution related to modern-day beavers.", 'Castorid - An adjective describing something relating to or characteristic of castorids, an extinct order which includes early beaver ancestors.']
